aws::graph::propositions: # Helicopter Pilot and Aircraft Modifications Information
Airbus Helicopters is developing dedicated amber HYDR caution lights for each hydraulic circuit (HYDR1 and HYDR2) on the CWP.
The dedicated amber HYDR caution lights integrate a flashing mode on the HYDR2 when the yaw servo hydraulic switch is in the "off" position.
The flashing mode indicates isolation of the yaw hydraulic circuit through a solenoid valve.
The dedicated amber HYDR caution lights modification has been incorporated on new production helicopters.
The dedicated amber HYDR caution lights will be introduced via a Service Bulletin to retrofit helicopters already in operation.
Airbus Helicopters is developing a future modification to replace the two stable positions [ACCU TST] push buttons.
The new [ACCU TST] push button will have a stable/momentary position similar to the design of the [CRANK] push button.
The current [ACCU TST] push button lights up when activated.
The current [ACCU TST] push button has no HYDR caution on the CWP when activated.
The pilot holds a Commercial certificate.
The pilot has Multi-engine land Airplane Rating.
The pilot has Helicopter Aircraft Rating.
The pilot has Airplane Instrument Rating.
The pilot has Helicopter Instrument Rating.
The pilot has no Instructor Rating.
The pilot's Medical Certification status is Unknown None.
The pilot is an Occupational Pilot.
The pilot is 57 years old.
The pilot is male.
The pilot occupied the Left seat.
The pilot used a 4-point restraint.
No Second Pilot was present.
No toxicology was performed on the pilot.
The pilot's last Flight Review or Equivalent was on December 18, 2013.

text:
# Pilot Information

## Dedicated Amber HYDR Caution Lights

dedicated amber HYDR caution lights for each hydraulic circuit (HYDR1 and HYDR2) on the CWP and which integrates a flashing mode on the HYDR2 when the yaw servo hydraulic switch is in the "off" position, isolating the yaw hydraulic circuit through a solenoid valve. This modification has been incorporated on new production helicopters and will be introduced via a Service Bulletin to retrofit helicopters already in operation.

## ACCU TST Push Button Modification

Additionally, the notice informed pilots that to mitigate the possibility of leaving the [ACCU TST] push button in the "on" position (currently the push button lights up when activated, but there is no HYDR caution on the CWP), Airbus Helicopters is developing a future modification to replace the two stable positions [ACCU TST] push buttons by a stable/momentary position [ACCU TST] push button similar to the design of the [CRANK] push button.
